questions.question: Which of these is an independent clause?
questions.explanation: This clause has a subject (birds) and a verb (sang) and can stand alone as a complete sentence.

questions.question: What type of clause is 'although it was late'?
questions.explanation: This clause has a subject and verb but can't stand alone as a sentence, making it a dependent clause.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The part of a sentence that contains the main idea is usually the _______ clause. (dependent / independent)
questions.explanation: The independent clause typically contains the main idea of a sentence.

questions.question: In the sentence 'I love ice cream, but I'm allergic to milk,' how many independent clauses are there?
questions.explanation: Both 'I love ice cream' and 'I'm allergic to milk' are independent clauses.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A clause that adds extra information to an independent clause is called a _______. (dependent clause / phrase)
questions.explanation: Dependent clauses add extra information but can't stand alone as sentences.

questions.question: Which of these is not a clause?
questions.explanation: 'Under the table' is a phrase, not a clause; it is a prepositional phrase.

questions.question: In the sentence 'Although it was cold, we went to the park,' which part is the independent clause?
questions.explanation: 'We went to the park' can stand alone as a sentence, making it an independent clause.

questions.question: Which of these is a dependent clause?
questions.explanation: This clause has a subject and verb but can't stand alone as a sentence, making it dependent.

questions.question: What makes a clause independent?
options: It has both a subject and a verb
It has a subject, and verb, and forms a complete thought
questions.explanation: An independent clause needs all three elements to stand alone as a sentence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In the sentence 'If it rains, we'll stay home,' the clause 'If it rains' is called the _______ clause. (dependent / independent)
questions.explanation: 'If it rains' cannot stand alone as a sentence, so it's the dependent clause.

questions.question: Which of these sentences contains both an independent and a dependent clause?
options: We went to the store and bought groceries.
Because it was sunny, we had a picnic.
The cat slept on the couch all day.
questions.explanation: 'Because it was sunny' is the dependent clause, and 'we had a picnic' is the independent clause.

questions.question: What is a phrase?
options: A group of words with a subject and verb
A group of words without a subject and verb
questions.explanation: A phrase is a group of words that work together but don't have both a subject and a verb.

questions.question: True or False: A phrase can be a complete sentence.
questions.explanation: A phrase cannot be a complete sentence because it lacks either a subject or a verb (or both).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'In the park' is an example of a _______ phrase. (Noun / Prepositional)
questions.explanation: This phrase starts with a preposition (in) and tells us where, making it a prepositional phrase.

questions.question: Which of these is a noun phrase?
questions.explanation: This phrase names a thing (balloon), so it's a noun phrase.

questions.question: Which of these is a prepositional phrase?
questions.explanation: This phrase starts with a preposition (on) and tells us where, making it a prepositional phrase.

questions.question: Which of the following is a phrase?
questions.explanation: A phrase is a group of words without a subject and verb. 'On the table' is a phrase.

questions.question: A phrase can stand alone as a complete sentence. (True / False)
questions.explanation: A phrase cannot stand alone as a sentence because it doesnâ€™t have a complete thought.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: A clause must have a ______ and a verb. (object / subject)
questions.explanation: A clause needs both a subject and a verb to form a complete idea.

questions.question: Which of the following is a phrase?
questions.explanation: 'In the morning' is a phrase because it lacks a subject and a verb.

questions.question: Which of the following is an independent clause?
questions.explanation: An independent clause can stand alone as a complete sentence. 'She finished her homework' is a complete sentence.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dependent clause?
questions.explanation: A dependent clause cannot stand alone as a complete sentence and needs more information. 'Since she was tired' needs more to make sense.

questions.question: Which of these is a complete thought and can stand alone?
questions.explanation: 'I love pizza' is an independent clause because it makes sense on its own.

questions.question: Which of the following is a dependent clause?
questions.explanation: 'After the storm passed' is a dependent clause because it needs more information to be a complete sentence.

questions.question: Which of the following contains both a dependent and an independent clause?
options: Before we left, we packed our bags
questions.explanation: 'Before we left' is the dependent clause, and 'we packed our bags' is the independent clause.
